reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s use of “resource-compatibility” in the moral-trade pathway (section 3) and the claim that compatibility is unlikely among linear, non-discounting views. This is an important premise for how optimistic we should be about trade-based routes to mostly-great futures, but it is not the paper’s sole pillar (it also argues at length about WAM/AM-convergence, blockers, threats, etc.), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique’s force is mainly evidential: it alleges insufficient definition/analysis and too-thin support for general claims (compatibility rarity; narcissism-of-small-differences generality). That plausibly weakens confidence in that sub-argument, but it doesn’t directly show the claim is false or that trade won’t work, so strength is moderate. The factual assertions about underspecification and reliance on illustrative examples appear accurate. The critique is clear, focused, and has little filler.
title: Resource-compatibility is underspecified yet central to the paper's conclusions
